docs.lead_paragraph: Science Times readers respond to last week's article about the campaign to promote breast-feeding.

docs.lead_paragraph: A bill requiring the Administration for Children's Services to regularly report to the City Council on key indicators was among three pieces of legislation signed into law yesterday by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. The mayor also signed into law a measure establishing a trust fund to pay for retired city workers' health benefits, and a bill temporarily easing a requirement that the Department of Correction use buses that run on alternative fuels. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Reports Required From Child Welfare

byline.original: By SEWELL CHAN (NYT); Compiled by John Sullivan

docs.lead_paragraph: Science Times received an extraordinary outpouring of letters -- more than 100, pro and con -- over last week's article ''Breast-Feed or Else,'' about the public health campaign to promote breast-feeding and discourage formula and bottles. A sampling follows; others are online at nytimes.com/science. To the Editor: As a breast-feeding mother, I appreciated your thoughtful, important article ''Breast-Feed or Else'' (June 13). It is important to add that the American Academy of Pediatrics recommends breast-feeding not only for six months, but exclusively for six months, and for as long thereafter as mutually desired by mother and child. Further, studies indicate that the composition of the breast milk becomes better over time, contrary to the popular belief that after six months it offers little benefit. Cammie Kim Lin New York To the Editor: When my son was born, I was intent on breast-feeding, regardless of the difficulties. But even with the help of my pediatrician and a lactation consultant, we needed to supplement with formula.
docs.abstract: Fourteen letters on June 13 article about breast-feeding infants; many cite need for changes in American culture, workplace and health care to enable mothers to give babies advantages of breast milk; some hold that article was demeaning to mothers who for variety of reasons cannot breast-feed; photo

docs.lead_paragraph: CHANGE AT HOME -- Executives from major cities have transformed Bentonville, Ark., Wal-Mart's hometown, into a mini-metropolis populated by Hindus, Muslims and Jews. The Jewish families in Benton County have become increasingly vocal proponents of religious neutrality in the county. [Page A1.] OFFICIAL TO JOIN GOLDMAN -- Deputy Secretary of State Robert B. Zoellick, below, is leaving the State Department to join Goldman Sachs as a managing director. Mr. Zoellick's departure from the administration, in which he also was United States trade representative, has been widely expected. [A3.] THINKING GLOBAL -- When Goldman Sachs lost Henry M. Paulson Jr. to the Treasury, the firm ceded a nonpareil globe-trotting client man. Its board is moving quickly to fill the void by naming Robert B. Zoellick as a vice chairman. Market Place. [C1.] RUNNING ON COAL -- Europe likes to think of itself as a place that has moved beyond its sooty industrial past. But with oil prices soaring and worries rising about the reliability of gas from Russia, Europe must depend heavily on that industrial-age relic, coal. [A1.] WHO'S NEXT? -- As Nokia and Siemens announced plans to merge their telecommunications equipment businesses, the unanswered question was not if, but when, the remaining giants would team up. [C1.] BURGERS IN FRANCE -- Denis Hennequin, president of McDonald's Europe, is the engineer of the restaurant chain's success in France. His skill lies in selling something quintessentially American to a people who purport to be against American culture. [C1.] SAKS REVIVES PETITE SECTION -- Scolded by short women across the country, Saks Fifth Avenue said it would re-establish its petite women's clothing department, which it had quietly dropped several months ago. [C1.] ENERGY LEGISLATION -- Since Hurricanes Katrina and Rita shut down refineries in the Gulf region last summer, accelerating the increase of gasoline costs, House members have introduced 267 energy-related bills and senators have introduced 210, a Congressional analysis says. [A11.] IRAQ CONTRACT CANCELED -- The Army Corps of Engineers said it had canceled a $99.1 million contract with Parsons, one of the largest companies working in Iraq, to build a prison north of Baghdad. [A9.] PLANS FOR THE GARDEN -- Steven Roth, chairman of Vornado Realty Trust, is quietly circulating a $7 billion plan for the district surrounding Madison Square Garden that includes moving the arena to what would be its fifth home. [A1.] INTERNET PHONE SUIT -- Vonage, the Internet telephone start-up, said it was being sued by Verizon Communications in a dispute over the underlying technology that allows voice calls to be delivered over the Internet. [C7.] CITIGROUP RETHINKS BRAND Citigroup senior managers have been meeting to review the company's brand, an effort that may spell the end of the ubiquitous red umbrella logo. Citigroup retained the umbrella, brand symbol of the Travelers Group, when it shed its insurance companies. Advertising. [C1.] CHIP SPEED RECORD -- Researchers at I.B.M. and the Georgia Institute of Technology are set to announce that they have broken the speed record for silicon-based chips. [C7.] ACCOUNTING BOARD APPOINTMENT -- A Federal Reserve governor, Mark W. Olson, was named chairman of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board, which regulates accounting firms. [C3.] ARCELOR DELAYS VOTE -- The steel giant Arcelor said that it would put off a crucial vote related to its 13 billion euro ($16.7 billion) deal with the Russian billionaire Aleksei Mordashov, raising questions about whether the deal was unraveling. [C3.] ARREST IN TAX CASE -- The owner of a machine tool maker was arrested at his California home and charged with orchestrating a tax fraud that cost the government nearly $20 million. [C3.] ONLINE ONE IMMIGRANT'S STORY -- As illegal immigrants in the United States have increased in numbers, so have the ranks of those who want to swindle them. A report can be found at nytimes.com/business. CHINA'S DARK CLOUDS -- In a video, David Barboza of The Times discusses how China's coal industry is creating an environmental and health care crisis. A report can be found at nytimes.com/business. IN THE IMPALA, A G.M. TALE -- The Chevy Impala shows how much progress General Motors has made and, how far behind it continues to fall. A report is at nytimes.com/business. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. DELTA AIR LINES said that it was notifying the federal pension insurer, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, that it intended to end its pilots' pension plan. (REUTERS) THE WARNER MUSIC GROUP said it signed an agreement to provide shortened versions of songs to China Unicom. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) THE APOLLO GROUP INC., a for-profit education company, said it had received a subpoena related to stock options. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) THE STONE ENERGY CORPORATION, the oil and natural gas producer that agreed in April to be sold to the Plains Exploration and Production Company, has determined that a $1.4 billion bid by Energy Partners was superior. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)
